The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

  • \nJune 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMay 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMarch 2012 (3)\n
    • \n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718647451:\n\n\n\n\n\nUse Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nUse Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search \n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n\n
\n

As mentioned in previous blog posts about web governance; the purpose of web governance is to make sure each employee knows what their responsibilities are in terms of the website, and what is expected of them. This is also the case when you work with the website's search function.

\n

Website search and web governance

\n

If you look at your website search from a web governance perspective, you'll find many areas of responsibility for which you'll need to have procedures and clearly appointed responsibilities. There are strategic decisions about what types of content you want to be available through the search function and how different content types should be prioritized. You also need to consider maintenance of search results, individual page searchability, and analysis of search statistics including; the presentation of findings.

\n

You'll typically have many different persons and roles sharing these responsibilities, and not just one person who is responsible for everything search related.

\n

Take individual page searchability as an example. This is about ensuring that the technical structure of the page makes it easy for the search engine to read and understand it, but it is also about making sure that the content on the page is written in a clear language so it is obvious what the page is about and how it differs from other pages on the website. These are two very different tasks, but they have the same overall purpose. This is an example of why clear areas of responsibility and procedures are important.

\n

Roles and Responsibilities

\n

The following are some of the tasks and areas of responsibilities that should be planned for in your web governance. These are coupled with roles, as examples of how it could be. There is no right way to do this, as roles and responsibilities depend on the size and ambitions of your web team.

\n
    \n
  • Aligning search with web strategy: This task is typically handled by the web team leader and includes deciding which content types to index and prioritize. Should self-service solutions and news content be prioritized higher than minutes from meetings and PDFs?
    • \n
  • Maintenance of search result pages: This task includes making custom rankings for specific searches (most popular, searches without results, or focus areas). This is done with the web strategy in mind and an eye on the analysis of search statistics. The task is normally handle by a central web team, but preferably by local editors responsible for a specific area.
    • \n
  • Analysis and interpretation of search statistics: This is often carried out by the central web team or a dedicated web analyst. It is important to have procedures for how and whom the results of the analysis is presented, so you make sure this knowledge is used.
    • \n
  • Control of 3rd party solutions and new solutions: All websites are in constant development; this means introducing new solutions and from time to time 3rd party solutions. If these new solutions contain information that should be available through the search function, it is important to have procedures for ensuring their searchability.
    • \n
\n

These are just some of the areas that you need to take into consideration in your web governance. It is important that you map the need of your organization, so you get into every corner.

\n

If you have subsites or sections on your website which have a search function of their own, then you might need more persons with the same responsibility but for different sections, while other responsibilities might be handled centrally for all the solutions.

\n

If you use specialized or advanced searches it is important that the responsibility for maintaining these is assigned.

\n

Web standards

\n

Most of the areas of responsibility should be supported by web standards, which define one specific way to do a task. Web standards will help you by eliminating doubts and making the website appear uniform. It is a great idea to spend some extra time on developing reasonable web standards.

\n

Here are some examples of web standards:

\n
    \n
  • Headings/titles of search results must be unique to avoid confusing users
    • \n
  • Self-service solutions should have the highest priority where applicable
    • \n
  • All searches that are made more than 20 times a month must have results
    • \n
  • All searches without results should be reviewed at least once a month
    • \n
\n

Summary

\n

A search function can be of great help to the users of the website, but it will need to work properly. Therefore, it is a good idea to include search responsibilities in your web governance.

\n

A well-functioning search can save your organization time and money, because users who find what they need on your website won't use the more expensive channels of communication. At the same time a good search function will provide you with valuable information about user's needs, which can be used in future work with your web strategy.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n\n
\n

    • \n

    • \n
  • \n\n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n

    \n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Roles and responsibilities in Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Recent Posts

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

  • How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?
    • \n
  • Website Redesign Checklist
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689804271:\n\n\n\n\n\n4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/23/13 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n

Web Error Checking

\n

Error checking is arguably the most obvious and important task in this list, because waiting for someone to complain about a mistake on your site isn’t a great “plan A.” It’s stressful, and the complaints always seem to come at the wrong time - to your boss, who freaks out.

\n

Strangely, while most seasoned web managers have experienced this scenario, most have never set up any real method of preventing it. Sure, your CMS has a spell check, but that doesn’t account for human error.

\n

If your CMS’s dictionary doesn’t have all your organization’s unique terminology, the web team will be ignoring the warnings faster than you can say “gosh, it would sure be swell if you guys could tell the difference between ‘their’ and ‘there.’”

\n

At the end of the day, the vast majority of organizations expect their web teams to manually comb through the site to find errors, which is a huge time sink and still doesn’t get the site 100% clean.

\n

It’s 2014. Humanity has landed robots on mars with self-piloting rocket cranes, created living human organs with a printer, and invented automatic methods of catching errors on your website. 

\n

Let the robots handle this so you can spend your time on more important things, like staying up to date on the internet’s astounding volume of silly cat videos.

\n

Web Analytics Reporting

\n

Status reports kill productivity. Generally, you can either do work or tell people about it.

\n

Unfortunately for you, lots of people need to see what’s going on with the website because it affects their work. They don’t all care about the same sections, so if you plan to include everyone you’re going to spend a ton of time creating custom reports.

\n

Automating your analytics reports is a silver bullet for time-sucking status reports. Everyone can see what’s happening with the website, and after the initial setup you don’t have to lift a finger to make it happen.

\n

When everyone is well informed about what’s happening with the website, they’re way more likely to stay engaged in website upkeep. Nobody likes working on something without ever seeing results.

\n

Let the robots have this one too.

\n

Web Inventories

\n

Many organizations routinely waste hundreds of hours taking inventory of all the media, links, etc. on their websites.

\n

To be clear, inventories aren’t a waste. Without them you might never catch the fact that Carol from Accounting is still listed under the “Contact Billing” form even though she retired last year. The waste is spending a month of man-hours getting it done.

\n

Again: space robots and designer internal organs. 
Modern technology has progressed to where you can scan your site and get a complete inventory with the click of a single button – and if you get the right tools, you don’t even have to click a button. Homer Simpson would be so proud.

\n

Web Governance Enforcement

\n

Consistency is key when establishing a web presence for your organization because the little things add up.  Should your phone numbers be formatted with dots or dashes? What’s the maximum file size allowed for uploaded photos? How do you catch hotlinked images?

\n

Instead of having a human try to give a once-over to every page created, let a robot do it. They’re fast, accurate, and unlike an intern they’ll never send you results formatted as a bunch of discombobulated screenshots dumped into a Microsoft Word document.

\n

So quit wasting your time doing things manually when there are perfectly good robots to do it for you.  Click here to check out what Siteimprove can automate for you.

\n

Do you know of a method of automation we haven’t mentioned here? Let us know in the comments.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n

\nApplying Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\n
\n

A year with Web Governance

\n

When we launched the new Siteimprove website a year ago, I was certain of one thing - We needed to be able to tightly control the website using Web Governance. First and foremost we needed to formulate and write down our Web Governance, as I mentioned in the blog post 'What is Web Governance?'.

\n

Write down your Web Governance

\n

Even though I had decided to scribble down our Web Governance, I quickly came to the conclusion that I was the website owner, and therefore solely responsible for the decisions and work on the website. Therefore why waste time on writing documents that were just for me?

\n

The only things we had on paper were a blog calendar, and guidelines for writing blog posts. The decision to not write anything down soon came back to haunt me, as we started having multiple editors posting jobs, webinars, news and events without any guidelines or procedures to control it.

\n

During the year we've established more procedures, but ultimately it has been done as a reaction to a need or problem, rather than as a proactive approach. The next step then for us now is the take those known procedures and incorporate them into a Web Governance manual. This manual will act as the backbone of established practice for the entire company, and will help new employees to adhere to it.   

\n

Clearly define roles and responsibilities

\n

Shortly after the launch of our new website it became clear that it wasn't feasible to merely have the US and UK websites as translated copies of the Danish website. Each country has its own news and events, and in time the diversity between country sites will only continue to increase. As a result our Marketing Coordinators in the US and UK were assigned content ownership of their respective websites.

\n

The only problem with this was that we hadn't clearly defined the ownership roles. So while copywriting and proofreading were under control it wasn't clear who was responsible for following up website usage with Siteimprove Analytics, or who maintained our internal search function.

\n

Now that we have added German and Swedish websites as well, the need for clearly defined roles and responsibilities is even more relevant.

\n

Use policies and procedures

\n

In a previous blog post I wrote about the policies and procedures of Web Governance. At Siteimprove we've primarily worked with procedures that describe how we do things; How do we ensure that images are cropped correctly, how do we post on social media, how do we structure job postings etcetera. This has helped us a lot in terms of ensuring uniformity across the board.

\n

You may ask yourself, "then why should I spend time writing down policies if there's already a set of procedures explaining how to do different tasks?" Policies are "laws," and they can guide you when you run into tasks for which you don't have procedures. Now while procedures may explain how to do a specific task, it is the policies that provide you with a reason as to why tasks should be solved in a specific way. And therefore they ease the implementation of Web Governance in the organization, as everybody is on the same page.

\n

One of the policies that we've spent time on is our language policy. It defines the tone of voice we use in our communication, both internally and externally, and also explains why we've chosen that specific voice. Our language policy is strongly rooted within our corporate strategy and our corporate values.

\n

The future

\n

During the next year we will improve our Web Governance and make it available to all within Siteimprove. This includes further defining roles and responsibilities, formulating more procedures, and the creation of further policies. This work will be tightly bound to our continued work strategy, ensuring that Web Governance and web strategy are aligned with our corporate strategy.

\n

Next time we get a new website, we'll think about Web Governance from day one, as it really does make the task easier and more comprehensible.

\n

If you've been involved in the creation or implementation of Web Governance, we would love to hear your thoughts in the comment section.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Make Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

    \n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\nA Look at Assistive Technology\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n\n

Let's go beyond the screenreader and look at some other technologies you may not be aware of or that has made significant changes to the way web pages are interpreted.

\n

What is Assistive Technology?

\n

Assistive technology is a term that includes devices used to assist with completing day-to-day tasks. People with disabilities may use them to eat, groom and travel.

\n

There's a broad spectrum of assistive devices, ranging from specialized motor vehicles to specifically modified computer input devices. While these are all considered assistive devices, our focus today is on computer or web-based assistive technologies, which may be in the form of either hardware or software. For example:

\n
    \n
  • Did you know that computer operating systems have many types of assistive technology already built in?
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Did you know that many people with disabilities don’t need additional devices to operate their computers and other equipment?
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Did you know that apps on mobile devices are extremely powerful and have become one of the largest areas of assistive technology?
    • \n
\n

Show Me the Assistive Technology

\n

When we discuss assistive technology, the most recognizable equipment is a screen reader. Screen readers come in different forms: software-based technology like JAWS®, and hardware-based technology like braille displays and screen magnifiers. JAWS® reads aloud the text on the screen and gives the user a set of tools for navigating and accessing web pages and screen content.

\n

A refreshable braille display is a device that displays braille characters by dynamically moving round-tipped pins up through holes in a flat surface. Blind users then read the braille output. Braille displays work in conjunction with screen reader software.

\n

Other assistive devices you may be less familiar with include devices which assist with both cognitive and mobility disabilities—switches. Switches often look like buttons, but may come in a wide variety of styles and functionality depending on the action used to activate them.

\n

 

\n

Want to learn more about Assistive Technology?

\n

We’re offering a free webinar to introduce you to assistive technology, and explain how it works. The webinar is a valuable way to understand some of the different tools your users rely on to complete their computer-based tasks. We’ll discuss:

\n
    \n
  • Microsoft and Apple operating systems
    • \n
  • Assistive software
    • \n
  • Assistive device hardware
    • \n
  • AT used by people with cognitive disabilities
    • \n
  • How Mobile Devices empower people with disabilities
    • \n
\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689802291:\n\n\n\n\n\nCelebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n

\nCelebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n\n
\n

The man who started and heads this growing company, Morten Ebbesen, remembers his early forays into the business world. ”Early on I knew that entrepreneurship would be a big part of my identity, and when I started Siteimprove it was just a couple of programmers and myself in a small Copenhagen office with a big dream.” Since then Siteimprove has gone from strength to strength, and it is now the world’s number one provider of web governance tools and solutions.

With more than 1500 accounts worldwide, and over 30,000 users, Siteimprove has played an integral role in revolutionizing the way the industry thinks about web governance. Previously an unfamiliar term, web governance is now the key benchmark for every website in the world.

With a plethora of customers across numerous verticals including healthcare, government, 
manufacturing, finance, higher education and law, Siteimprove provides cleverly simple website management tools for some of the world’s best-known companies and organizations including US Bank, Mayo Clinic, London School of Economics, John Hopkins University, Harvard Web Publishing and British Library.

Performing over 64 million website checks a week may seem daunting but for Ebbesen this is just the start of a long and successful future.

“Having succeeded as much as we have in the past 10 years a lot of people may expect us to slow down but I have no plans of that. With an ever changing market I feel certain that Siteimprove will only continue to grow and mature, and that this will correlate into significant growth, not only logistically but also financially.” 

As Siteimprove heads into it’s next decade the focus is strongly on innovation. New product developments are already in the pipeline, as are a range of new and exciting innovations that are guaranteed to again change the way the industry views hot topics such as accessibility. With the world at it’s feet the future looks very bright for this uniquely entrepreneurial company.

\n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8590048741:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Create Accessible PDFs\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

How to Create Accessible PDFs

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

A Step-by-Step Guide to Creating Accessible PDFs

\n

Ensuring that the documents available on your website are accessible for everyone is important for every organization. Unfortunately, the process of actually making your documents accessible to everyone isn't common knowledge. This guide will teach you how to create accessible PDFs using Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign. 

\n

This guide contains:

\n
    \n
  • Overview of accessibility guidelines
    • \n
  • How to meet guidelines with Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign
    • \n
  • Steps for creating the PDF
    • \n
  • How to check PDFs for accessibility
    • \n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8729873411:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nHow Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n\n

What is Net Neutrality?

\n

According to Tim Wu, Professor at Columbia Law School and pioneer of the Net Neutrality terminology, “The idea is that a maximally useful public information network aspires to treat all content, sites, and platforms equally.”

\n

Essentially, it’s the idea that all legal content, and content sources, are viewed as equals by the companies whom we pay to provide us with Internet access. So, cat videos on YouTube and entire seasons of Toddlers & Tiaras on Netflix are given the same merit as an E-Book on Aeronautical Energy Efficiency from the NASA blog.

\n

Net Neutrality is the only thing preventing Internet Service Providers from dictating which companies, and which content, will receive preferential treatment.

\n

Why do Internet Providers Want it Changed?

\n

The argument being made by Internet Service Providers (ISPs) is that sites which are responsible for higher traffic and larger amounts of data downloads (streaming sites like YouTube and Netflix) should be required to pay more in order for users to access their content.

\n

This idea of creating a “fast lane” is not attainable in regards to a globally shared broadband internet, as increasing speeds for some, means decreasing speeds for others. Think of it as a highway where one lane is reserved entirely for those who are able to afford the fee for using it. The rest of the users would be relegated to the other lanes, causing more congestion.

\n

How Will This Impact Businesses and Consumers?

\n

One would think that ISPs should have the right to charge certain content providers more money if they are responsible for higher traffic and data downloads. The issue becomes one of equal access, as companies with large budgets can afford to pay a fee for higher speeds, smaller companies and startups would find themselves at a severe disadvantage. The outcome would see consumers being forced to use these “first class” sites as a result of the faster speeds, while the slower sites would become “second class” and see a steep drop in traffic and service quality.

\n

What would happen if a small, non-profit company were providing crucial information to millions of people, but their ISP decided to charge them a large fee in order to maintain their service quality?

\n

Another concern is Internet Service Providers being allowed to “double-dip” by charging companies an extra fee on top of the one they already charge to consumers. This would effectively punish smaller companies for not being able to compete with the large wallets of their competitors and leave consumers with little choice as to which sites they are able to use effectively. Further concern would be raised if the new fees for content providers led to an increase in pricing for services like Netflix, Amazon Prime, or even Google.

\n

Another area of contention is that ISPs would essentially be allowed to favor their own content by providing it at faster speeds, while “throttling” the speeds allotted to their competitors. For example, Comcast could boost speeds towards their own On-Demand services, while decreasing speeds for Netflix or Amazon Prime.

\n

What Can You Do?

\n

The topic of Net Neutrality is not a new one. ISPs have been clamoring for the ability to charge premium fees to large companies for more than a decade, and the current political implications stretch back as far as 2007, when then Presidential candidate Barack Obama promised to uphold the principals of Net Neutrality and refrain from appointing an FCC Chairman who would seek to circumvent the principles of Net Neutrality.

\n

On May 20, 2014, the FCC will propose its new Net Neutrality rules to congress, and while the debate is likely to continue for some time, there are a few ways in which you can help to preserve the ideals of an open Internet.

\n

Politely contact your state legislator before May 20, 2014 and share your thoughts.

\n

Politely contact FCC Chairman, Tom Wheeler before May 20, 2014 and share your thoughts.

\n

Politely share your thoughts with the FCC before May 20, 2014.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\nHow The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n\n

What Does Google Want?

\n

With their Hummingbird update (released in Sept 2013), Google made a definitive statement about what they want to be. They no longer want to provide search results evenly across companies and industries. Google wants to be an information broker. They want to provide users with the best quality content; content that is relevant to the search and is most likely to satisfy the user’s needs.

\n

What Google wants now is high quality content. Feed Google what it wants, or they will eat you instead.

\n

How Does Google Find High Quality Content?

\n

The Hummingbird update presents a shift from keywords & link building, to content relevance and connections through:

\n

Entities & Co-Occurrences

\n

An Entity is the term used to describe the most commonly searched content- People, places, things, and ideas. Google wants to present the most crucial information that it can about these entities, that’s why the new search results will pull a range of news stories, bios, facts and statistics, and images. The goal is to answer any question you could possibly have.

\n

A Co-Occurrence (or Co-Citation) refers to the shared relationships between Entities across unique websites. Obviously, more relationships will result in a higher search ranking.

\n

Co-Occurrence works like this:

\n

\n

Site A links to Site B and Site C, however Site B and Site C do not link to one another. Google will still imply a relationship between the two, given their shared relationship with Site A.

\n

The more QUALITY, RELEVANT sites that you are able to form relationships with, the more Co-Occurrences Google will be able to identify, and the higher your search rankings will become.

\n

What Does This Mean For Your SEO?

\n

Basically, it means you can’t fool Google anymore. Their robots are faster, smarter, and WAY better at searching the internet than you are. There are over 950 million unique websites on the Internet, and Google has read them all. More than once. Today.

\n

Don’t worry, this is all GOOD NEWS for those who are creating useful, relevant content. So long as you are consistently publishing information, news, articles, or studies that people are searching for, the search engine gods will look upon you favorably.

\n

How Can You Improve Your SEO Now?

\n

Improve your content

\n

This goes without saying. If you’re not putting out quality content, you’ll be ignored by people and robots alike. Make it useful, informative, and easy to consume.

\n

Become an entity

\n

This is what we meant by, “Give Google what it wants.” – i.e. contact information, images, news stories, and biographies. Putting this information on your website, social media pages (especially Google+), and blog will provide Google with more sources and more reason to increase your rankings.

\n

Build relationships

\n

This is where QUALITY outbound links will come into play. By linking to reputable sites with relevant content (e.g. Universities linking to a scholarly journal) you’re telling Google that your site is interested in providing reliable information. If reputable sites take notice and begin linking back to you, that’s a double whammy!

\n

Spoiler alert: Google will give preferential treatment to those who link to their other channels. So if you have a YouTube channel or Google+ page, be sure to create and share relevant content across your channels.

\n

Make your site easy for search engines to crawl

\n

By properly structuring and tagging your site’s HTML, search engine crawlers will be able to easily identify the content on your page. Luckily for you, Google, Bing, and Yahoo! got together back in 2011 to create Schema.org. The goal behind Schema.org was to create a unified set of “schema”, or HTML tags, for webmasters to use when marking up sections of HTML code.

\n

Using the schema/HTML tags found on Schema.org will ensure that you are playing in the same sandbox as the world’s biggest search engines.

\n

 

\n

For more help on crafting useful content that people need, robots want, and your business will benefit from, download our on-demand webinar. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

 

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8830387041:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n\n

The answer lies in your content. Content is the currency of the digital generation. Once upon a time, companies were able to buy customers simply by spending the most money on advertising and mass marketing. Now, it’s the companies who spend time creating valuable, engaging content that earn customers. The content you share online is an opportunity to show off your brand personality, demonstrate your knowledge, and engage with your audience. Writing dry, lifeless content will bore your readers and prevent them from making a meaningful connection with your organization.

\n

So. What are some reasons why your web content isn’t resonating with your targeted audience?

\n

It’s Not Engaging

\n

For one reason or another, readers aren’t making a connection with you or your content. The digital generation has terrible A.D.D, so you need to give them a reason to stick around. Make it entertaining, give it a personality, anything to make readers remember their experience. For example: If you’re a bank, provide your readers with some eye-opening statistics about retirement planning and they’ll be more likely to look for more information or give you a call.

\n

It’s Not Relevant

\n

Your content could be Pulitzer Prize winning stuff, but if it’s not written for the correct audience, the only “likes” you’ll be getting will be from mom and dad. Listen to your audience and tailor your content based on their needs. For example: Health care providers could share the results of a new medical study on cancer, or how they recently invested in new, cutting-edge technology to demonstrate their commitment to providing top quality care.

\n

It’s Too “Salesy”

\n

Your readers are looking for answers and guidance, not to be sold to. When they’re ready to buy, they’ll let you know. Until then, nurture their needs by providing them with useful information to keep them interested, and to keep your brand at the front of the pack. Telling readers how your product/service is the answer to their problems, without actually proving why, won’t get you very far and is likely to leave a bad taste in the reader’s mouth. Pay it forward, people.

\n

It’s Overbearing

\n

There’s two possibilities here: the first is that you’re bombarding your readers with constant updates and they’re getting burnt out. The second is that your content is too dense and you’re running into “too long; didn’t read” syndrome. Remember to keep your content focused, spread out your updates/notifications, and if you have A LOT of information consider breaking it up into a series of smaller updates.

\n

It Doesn’t Empathize

\n

This goes back to the idea of making a human connection with your readers. If your content makes readers say, “Hey, we have that same problem!” Bam. You've got them hooked. Your goal should be to show them that you understand their challenge, and that you have the information/solution that they’re looking for. For example: A college or university could appeal to potential students who also work full-time by communicating how a busy schedule shouldn't prevent them from getting access to a good education, which is why they’ve created flexible and online courses in order to help students find time for both work and education.

\n

 

\n

Your website content is crucial to reaching your online goals, but you’ll only reach them if it resonates with your audience as well.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8873241071:\n\n\n\n\n\nOn-Demand Webinar: Why Semantic Markup Matters For Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

On-Demand Webinar: Why Semantic Markup Matters For Web Accessibility

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n

Semantics and accessibility are a part of HTML by design. Still, they are not useful unless used appropriately. Understanding how to write semantic code properly means knowing how that code works, and how users and machines will read it. In this webinar, we look at: 

\n
    \n
  • WCAG Guideline 1.3, Adaptable
    • \n
  • Semantic HTML structure \n
      \n
    • Content, Presentation, and Behavior
      • \n
    • Semantic vs. Non-semantic (Presentational) tags
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • The Web Standards Model\n
      \n
    • Structural Semantics, Text Level Semantics, WIA-ARIA, Microdata, and RDFa
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • Bonus Section- Semantic Markup vs. Semantic Classes 
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\nRead More\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n
\nRead More\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n
\n

Siteimprove Training Request

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Build your knowledge, learn best practices, and get the most out of your Siteimprove investment. 

\n

Whether you're looking for new training for your entire team, a quick refresher course for experienced users, or a deeper dive into a new product enhancement or feature, our Customer Experience team is committed to offering Siteimprove customers the best and most inclusive training. 

\n

Fill out the form to the right and a member of our Customer Experience team will contact you to develop a free training program based on your needs.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n 9028099691:\n\n\n\n\n\nRoles & Responsibilities on a Web Team\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: Roles & Responsibilities On a Web Team

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Yet, roles and responsibilities on many digital teams have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has often led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well tension among staff over “who does what”.

In this webinar we’ll explore how to restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your people need. Among the topics we will cover are:

\n
    \n
  • The difference between a person's "role" & their "responsibilities"
    • \n
  • How to write a good job description
    • \n
  • How many people to have on your team and with what skills
    • \n
  • How to organize your team
    • \n
  • Deciding who should have overall responsibility for the website
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8844923131:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Must-Have Web Accessibility Handbook\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

The Must-Have Web Accessibility Handbook

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility is about allowing people with and without disabilities to have access to the information they want and need from your website. With reports of 1 in 5 people claiming some sort of disability, 20% of the population is just too large of a group to ignore.

\n

Download this complimentary handbook and learn everything you need to know to make your website accessible.

\n

\n

This handbook includes:

\n

Part 1:

\n
    \n
  • Overview to Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Roles and Responsibilities of Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility Resources
    • \n
\n

Part 2:

\n
    \n
  • Beginners Guide to Siteimprove Accessibility
    • \n
  • Who should use the Siteimprove Accessibility Tool?
    • \n
  • How to Check WCAG 2.0 Accessibility Issues
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
