Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Map your current web governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Tell users about your cookies

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\nHow to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n\n

I actively chose not to title this blog, “Web Governance Hacks” for two reasons. First, because I’m a snob and I hate “click bait” content. Second, and more importantly, because that’s not what web governance is. It’s not a piece of gum that you use to plug the hole in the dam. Web governance is a combination of long-term strategies and systems that allow your web team to make the most of their time and energy.

\n

There are four major commodities that typically impact how organizations maintain their website: people, time, tools, and money. Let’s dive into these areas and look at how web governance can help improve your site without feeling like you’re trying to get access to nuclear launch codes.

\n

People

\n

As our good friend Shane Diffily has already shared, people are the most important piece of any web governance system. So what can you do to make up for a lack of (wo)manpower?

\n

When you’re stretched too thin, it can feel like you’re constantly putting out fires and coming up with solutions that don’t actually solve the problem, they just slow the burn rate. A web governance strategy will help to clearly define the roles and responsibilities for your team, and help eliminate confusion or miscommunication when tackling website issues. You can put people in charge of specific tasks or sections of the website, either way they’ll be accountable for progress/success, and know exactly when to step in and address problems.

\n

Once you’ve clearly identified the “who, what, when, where, why”, your team can be more proactive, and focus on improving your website’s quality and functionality, while leaving room and establishing a plan for handling unexpected issues.

\n

Time

\n

There’s only so much in a day, and that thing you thought would only take ten minutes is now rolling into hour five and crushed any dreams you had of taking a lunch break. Organizations can hire more, spend more, and “synergize” more, but time is a finite resource, so you need to be efficient with how you use it.

\n

A web governance strategy (and tool) will enable you to prioritize errors based on urgency and the impact they have on your website. If a broken link is discovered on your website, but you don’t know how many pages it’s affecting, or how long it’s been there, you might be wasting time and energy fixing something that no one else even knows about.

\n

Web governance will help determine how these issues are prioritized, and how your team responds to them, meaning their time will be spent on projects that will have the greatest impact.

\n

Tools

\n

Carpenters need hammers, farmers need plows, and accountants need calculators. Without the proper tools, people will be less effective at their doing their jobs. The same goes for digital marketers.

\n

By itself, a web governance tool is incredibly powerful; automating the time-consuming manual tasks of checking for broken links and misspellings, catching web accessibility issues, monitoring for SEO errors, and reporting on site performance and down-time.

\n

Your web governance tool can also amplify the effectiveness of other tools, like your CMS (content management system). Your web governance tool can alert you to errors on your website, but also provide a seamless transition into your CMS, allowing you to address the error quickly and easily.

\n

While your team is hard at work creating content, improving your web design, and dissecting analytics data, a web governance tool will be meticulously scanning your website for errors that would either take too long for your team to discover, or go unnoticed entirely.

\n

Money

\n

Budgets are fickle creatures. Constantly shrinking and shifting, forcing you to find creative solutions in order to get things done. Since most executives speak the language of “results”, employing a stop-gap strategy for addressing your website issues probably won’t do you any favors when it comes to asking for a bigger allowance.

\n

So, how can you use web governance to navigate the treacherous waters of corporate budgets, roadblocks, and red tape? By speaking the same language as the people holding the checkbook.

\n

Lay out a clear plan for how your team will employ a web governance strategy (and tools) to help the organization reach its business goals. Let’s say your organization wants to increase the sales of a specific product. If you can demonstrate how your web team’s new strategy will provide the structure, stability, and focus needed to help reach that goal, you’ll be able to convince the suits to open up their piggybank and provide you with the resources needed.

\n

Web governance let's you work smarter, not harder. Get your stretegy off the ground with this on-demand webinar from Shane Diffily.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of renjith krishnan at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9780103281:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove's Webinar: Crying Wolf - The Section 508 Refresh\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

Webinar: Crying Wolf - The Section 508 Refresh

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Wednesday, March 25, 2015 at 1pm CDT

\n

Your accessibility consultant has been warning you for months - even years. Just wait; it's coming. Is this a case of crying wolf, or will the Section 508 refresh ever happen? Well good people, it's going to happen eventually, and when it does, will you be ready?

\n

In March's webinar, we’re going to discuss what it will mean for you and your team once the requirements are finally updated. Spoiler alert: you may be more prepared than you think!

\n

We're going to take a look at:

\n
    \n
  • The history of Section 508 guidelines
    • \n
  • Current Section 508
    • \n
  • What is changing
    • \n
  • WCAG 2.0 AA requirements
    • \n
  • How to educate your team
    • \n
\n
\n

About the Host: Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the globe at multiple conferences and events, most recently in Stockholm for a web accessibility conference. 

\n

Optional Extra: Stick around after the webinar for a quick 15 min overview of our Web Governance Suite software.

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Don't Get Schooled by Web Accessibility - 5 Focuses for Back to School

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n8/20/13 10:36 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It’s that time of the year again: Students are lining up to buy textbooks and signing up for classes. BUT WAIT! You have a million back-to-school tasks to complete AND there is a line of students with accessibility requests at your door. Unsure of where to start? Keep calm and accessibility on! We’ll give you five critical places to focus your accessibility efforts first.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Take a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

    \n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

  • \nFebruary 2014 (2)\n
    • \n
  • \nJanuary 2014 (4)\n
    • \n

    • \n

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792122991:\n\n\n\n\n\nMap your current web governance\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nMap your current web governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n\n
\n

Web Governance Terms

\n

Before you start mapping your current situation there are some Web Governance terms I would like to introduce to make sure we are on the same page. When I've covered the different terms you should have an idea about your current state of Web Governance, or at least the tools to find out.

\n

Web policy

\n

A web policy is the highest level of abstraction within Web Governance. A web policy is a set of rules and constraints for how your organization works in regards to web. The purpose of a web policy is to protect the organization from risk and to ensure the utilization of your organization's full web potential. Web policies within an organization should be few and rarely changed. Web policies affect the entire organization.

\n

An example of a web policy that many organizations either have implemented or thought about implementing within the last few years is a social media policy. A social media policy must cover the organizations use of social media, what tone to use, how, when, who and how much work with social media the organization should engage in. A social media policy SHOULDN'T be limited to only cover a certain social network. Those sorts of limitations belong in web standards, not web policies.

\n

Web standards

\n

Web standards are explicit rules describing the parameters, limitations and details to be followed by those involved in the development of content, data, web applications, etc. for the organization. These rules are focused on assurance of the organization's web quality, and should be updated frequently to keep up with the general development of the World Wide Web. An organization should have many web standards covering everything from non-technical aspects like design to very technical things such as server infrastructure. Web standards can typically be placed within four categories:

\n
    \n
  1. Design & contents
    2. \n
  2. Information architecture and access
    3. \n
  3. Web tools and applications
    4. \n
  4. Network and server infrastructure
    5. \n
\n

A couple of examples of web standards are:

\n
    \n
  • All pages on the organization's website must comply with WCAG 2.0 AA accessibility standards.
    • \n
  • Response time for the internal search engine must not exceed 1.5 sec.
    • \n
  • Your company email must not be used for social media activities.
    • \n
\n

The number and details of web standards will vary from organization to organization, but it is important to remember that web standards are not procedures or methods describing in detail how to publish web content.

\n

Input, decisions and stakeholders

\n

When working with policies and standards within the different categories, there will be a series of stakeholders either directly or indirectly affected by the decisions. Some of these will give input to the creation of the standards; others will be responsible for making the decision about the final versions of the standards.

\n

In regards to mapping your current state of web governance it is interesting to look at who gives input and who makes the decisions within the different categories. The organizational archetypes who are normally involved in input and decisions are:

\n
    \n
  • C-level managers
    • \n
  • Business managers
    • \n
  • Specialist (IT, social media, communications, accessibility and so on)
    • \n
  • Everybody (anarchy)
    • \n
\n

Typically it is one or more of the above who provides input to a specific standard, and then a manager who makes the decision and as such is responsible for the decision. If there is an area without clear input and decision rights, and where everybody does as the like, we call that anarchy. This is often seen within organization's social media presence.

\n

Your Web Governance

\n

Now we are at the point where you should map you current state of web governance. Hopefully you already have a good idea of how it looks, but to make it even more visible you can write in the archetypes or even specific business units in the table below.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

 

\n		\n

Web policy

\n		\n

Web standards - Design & Content

\n		\n

Web standards - information architecture & access

\n		\n

Web standards - Web tools & applications

\n		\n

Web standards - Network & server infrastructure

\n
\n

Input

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n
\n

 Decision

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n		\n

 

\n
\n

 

\n

Now you have an idea of how your web governance is, and if you have come this far you are probably ready to work on improving your web governance. In future blog posts I will go into more depth on how you can work with your Web Governance. If you can't wait that long, have a look at the WelchmanPierpoint blog, which contains multiple interesting posts about the topic

\n

Follow-up

\n

It doesn't make much sense for you to make policies and standards if they aren't being followed, but running manual compliance checks on large websites is confusing and time consuming. Fortunately, there are tools available to help you. [Warning: shameless plug] Our Siteimprove Web Governance Suite makes it easy to monitor your web presence helps support the processes and responsibilities.

\n

Share your own experiences in working with Web Governance and drop us a line in the comments below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127051:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Partners with One North Interactive\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nSiteimprove Partners with One North Interactive\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/11/13 2:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, Inc. the world’s leading providers of web governance solutions have today announced a new partnership with creative agency One North Interactive LLC (One North) who serve the strategic, creative and technological needs of leading law firms.

\n
\n
\n

The mutually beneficial partnership will see One North offer their existing and new legal customers Siteimprove’s market leading web analytics solution. Currently serving more than 1,500 organizations worldwide, of which more than 20 are Am Law 100 firms, Siteimprove CEO Torben Rytt sees the partnership as the ideal way for Siteimprove to cement their stronghold within the legal industry.

“As an industry leader within our own field it was essential to us that we find our equal to partner with, which we definitely did with One North. Both of us pride ourselves on providing the best available service to our customers and through this partnership we look forward to offering One North’s clients a viable way of using analytics to stay ahead of their competition” said Rytt.

For One North CEO and Founder John Simpson, the decision to collaborate with Siteimprove and position it as the agency’s best-in-class web governance provider was an easy one.  

“Creating a seamless web user experience is critical for One North and our clients. We’re delighted to partner with Siteimprove, as we are focused on providing our clients with the tools needed to ensure consistent, high-quality user experiences. We also believe that more in-depth analytics will enable clients to not only quantify their success, but also help them understand user behavior and trends. We’re excited to be working together. ”

\n

In the future, Siteimprove and One North look forward to further strengthening their professional relationship, and to continue offering current and future clients the innovative services and solutions that both are known for.

For more information on Siteimprove please visit www.siteimprove.com

\n

About Siteimprove:
Repeatedly named one of the 100 best companies to work for, Siteimprove provides organizations of all shapes and sizes with tools that make website management and maintenance easier and more affordable. Founded in Denmark in 2003, Siteimprove has a global presence with offices in the UK, US and Germany.

\n

Media Contacts:

Siteimprove, Inc.  
Jessica O’Sullivan, Strategic PR & Marketing Manager
(612) 545-5662 jos@siteimprove.com

\n

One North Interactive 
Jennifer Bullett, Managing Director, Marketing
(312) 873-6875 jbullett@onenorth.com

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127281:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat's up with 'not provided'?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nWhat's up with 'not provided'?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\n
\n

The only keywords you will continue to see in Siteimprove SEO and Analytics, are keywords from other search engines like Bing and Yahoo, as well as keywords from Google Adwords ads. It is important to emphasize that this is not just a problem for Siteimprove. All other analysis tools have the same problem - the data will simply no longer exist. Not even in Google Analytics. 

\n

What do we do then?

\n

That is actually a pretty good question, and Siteimprove unfortunately cannot provide data that no longer exists. However, we do have some good advice on how to get an idea of ​​what users are looking at despite [not provided]:

\n
    \n
  • Look at statistics from your internal search in Siteimprove Analytics. Your users might not be using the exact same keywords when searching in Google as they do in your internal search, but at least you get an idea of ​​what topics your users are interested in, and what keywords they typically use. We often see that these are not necessarily the same keywords that you would use or that you think they would use to find your products or services.
    • \n
  • Look at statistics of your most popular entry pages in Siteimprove SEO. Although you can no longer see exactly what keywords users have searched for to get to that page, you can probably make a pretty qualified guess at which keywords they must have used - if you look at the page content and the keywords that are included in the text.
    • \n
  • Look at historical data from Siteimprove Analytics. Even though, in the future, keyword data will not be provided by Google, you will always be able to retrieve historical data in the tool.
    • \n
\n

What is Siteimprove going to do?

\n

Siteimprove will be reviewing the tools in order to address the consequences of the disappearing keyword data. There will be tables and columns that will no longer provide useful information and some of them will be removed completely while others will be adapted to the new situation.

Others will remain as they are, so that you can continue to view historical keyword data.

Last but not least: we will focus on developing new and exciting features to help our customers improve their websites despite [not provided].

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792129971:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Accessibility and the Law\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWeb Accessibility and the Law\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n

Time & Resources

\n

For some organizations, they don’t have the time, resources, or technical knowledge required to make their website functionally usable to those with disabilities. Instead, they aim to meet the minimum requirements, which may protect them from legal or regulatory issues, but will prevent users with varying disabilities from interacting with the site in a reasonable way.

\n

For other organizations, they are either willfully or blissfully unaware of the issues that can arise from having a website that doesn’t meet web accessibility standards.

\n

Legal Action

\n

The legal implications can be serious. A parent recently sued the Seattle Public School District because she is no longer able to access the school district resources needed to help her children with their schoolwork. She claims that the school district’s new website developer made changes that were no longer compatible with her JAWS Screen Reader, a common device that allows the visually impaired to have on-screen text translated into audio. 

\n

Resources

\n

These situations are easy for organizations of all shapes and sizes to avoid, and we have a library of knowledge resources available to help ensure that your website provides the best experience possible for all users.

\n

On-Demand Webinars:

\n

Introduction to Web Accessibility

\n

Cognitive Disabilities & Web Accessibility

\n

Why Semantic Markup Matters for Web Accessibility

\n

eBooks:

\n

How to Create Accessible PDFs

\n

For more helpful information about Web Accessibility.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Vichaya Kiatying-Angsulee at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

\n

\nWatch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n\n

So, like many of my friends and family have been asking me, “Kelsey, what exactly are you going to be doing there?”

\n
    \n
  1. Find, meet, and attempt to befriend a kangaroo
    2. \n
  2. Meet with as many current and potential customers as possible
    3. \n
  3. Learn as MUCH AS POSSIBLE about the Australian market and its web teams’ needs
    4. \n
  4. Get out of the freezing Minnesota weather
    5. \n
  5. Last but not least, Siteimprove & Deakin University are collaborating to host an Accessibility speaking event. Details below:
    6. \n
\n

Web Accessibility Event @ Deakin University

\n

We will be covering how to address accessibility issues on your website in order to reach a AA level of compliance, and strategies to make web accessibility a part of your day-to-day work on the web.

\n

Thursday, November 13
12:30pm – 2:30pm

\n

Burwood Corporate Center
221 Burwood Highway
Building BC, Level 2
Burwood, Victoria 3125

\n

\n \n \n

\n

My Schedule

\n

I’ll be splitting my time between Sydney and Melbourne, so please let me know if you would like to schedule some time to learn more about Siteimprove or how we can help you improve the way you manage your website. 

\n

Sydney: October 27 – November 6
Melbourne: November 7 – November 18

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Overall, the 4 weeks that I’ll be in Australia are to fully immerse myself in the culture, lifestyle, demands, and needs of the market so that I can work with our product team to create a more useful tool for you!

\n

Follow Me

\n

Since I’m an avid photographer, you can also follow my journey in pictures on the Siteimprove Instagram account.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792135961:\n\n\n\n\n\nSimple, yet lethal SEO no-no's\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n

\nSimple, yet lethal SEO no-no's\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n


Forgetting to dot your I's and cross your T's

\n

Imagine if from this point onwards you decided never to add a subject to your emails again. Besides ticking off your boss and colleagues you'd probably also find out that you didn't get many answers. The same applies to forgetting to title your web pages or having the same title on duplicate pages. Without an engaging and descriptive title not only will Google struggle to find you, but your conversion rate will suffer. It's also important to remember that your title tag is what people are going to see when they are looking in search engines, bookmarks, or link to your page via social networks. If you're just using your company name or some other useless generic text then you should kick yourself, hard, right now.       

\n

Being too flashy for your own good

\n

While there may be occasions when flash is needed for websites, these occasions are few and far between. Designing parts or heaven forbid a whole website in flash is going to make it hard, if not impossible for search engines to read you. Flash also has the tendency to annoy users - as this website, aptly titled The World's Worst Website, so excellently demonstrates. If users feel like reaching for a stiff drink after being on your site something's going wrong.

\n

Using irrelevant keywords

\n

Knowing how to correctly use keywords is essential for good SEO. There's nothing worse than spending time and money on formulating a great site or blog to have no-one read it. Finding the right keywords for your business can be tricky, especially when you consider that many potential customers may misspell keywords or use different terminology from what you'd expect. To find the right keywords it's essential to use web diagnostic tools, as well as your own analytics to give you an insight into what terms are actually converting for you.

\n

Thinking Sex Appeal doesn't matter
"Sex appeal" and "URLs" may not exactly go together, but with evidence suggesting that long URLs act as a deterrent to users clicking rates, it is important to consider how your URLs appear. SEO expert and author Stephen Spencer found that short URLs are often clicked on twice as often as long ones. By comparison, long URLs can draw attention away from your search engine listing, helping to place the emphasis onto your competitors instead.   

\n

Linking like it's 1999

\n

Just as peeling paint can make a room look outdated so too can overly simple anchor text links. The soul crushingly common 'click here', 'read me' and 'buy me' links are for many people synonymous with outdated websites and outdated businesses. These ugly links needn't happen though as controlling your links is one of the many little things you can do to improve your SEO. So make sure that when you're linking you're using optimized anchor text.  

\n

Ana-what-ics?

\n

All too often people seem to think of SEO and Analytics as existing completely separately of each other. Clever people however will know that neither are anything without the other. Understanding how to do SEO better also requires understanding your users, their behavior, traffic hubs, preferred search engines and so forth. The more you know about your site and users, the better you'll be able to optimize content for searchers. 

If you've enjoyed reading this, do the kind thing and share it!  

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

    • \n
  • \nMay 2013 (3)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2013 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMarch 2013 (1)\n
    • \n
  • \nFebruary 2013 (2)\n
    • \n
  • \nJanuary 2013 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nDecember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nNovember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nOctober 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nSeptember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nAugust 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nJuly 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nJune 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMay 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMarch 2012 (3)\n

Recent Posts

\n

Six Common Misunderstandings About Your CMS

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n6/20/13 2:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

When speaking about web governance (diagnosis, compliance and maintenance) of website quality assurance and accessibility, the common response is, our Content Management System (CMS) has a solution for this. However, this is the common misunderstanding.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792132201:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Governance from an SEO Point of View\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
