Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWeb Governance from an SEO Point of View\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n\n
\n

Today many people who work with websites are aware that they should "do something for SEO," but they don't necessarily have a lot of thoughts about why and how, or what they really want to achieve - aside from "more traffic" and "more visibility."

\n

Web governance can strengthen the position of your SEO efforts in the organization and help ensure that search engine optimization has a purpose and is actually being executed, instead of it going from being a good idea to a random set of actions that might result in nothing but a waste of time and resources.

\n

Web Strategy

\n

First and foremost, SEO needs to be included in the organization's web strategy, but SEO is not a goal in itself. There should be a desire to obtain some relevant, measurable and realistic objectives with SEO as the facilitator. All organizations / companies are different and will have different goals.

\n

Common objectives can include:

\n
    \n
  • A number of completed self-service process completed
    • \n
  • A number of online purchases completed
    • \n
  • A number of unique keywords used to find the site
    • \n
  • One percent increase in visits from search engines
    • \n
\n


One of the objectives of SEO being part of the strategy alongside other web disciplines is that there is a greater chance of success if SEO is not seen as an isolated discipline. Although an SEO campaign is successful in increasing the number of visits via search engines, there is no guarantee that it leads to the desired increase in the number of completed self-service processes. It may be because the SEO campaign has not managed to attract relevant traffic or hasn't led the traffic to the relevant landing pages. But it may also be because the link to start the self-service process is tucked away at the bottom of the page, so no one notices it, or because the self-service process is not user-friendly enough and therefore often not completed.

In both cases you will get a better result if your SEO efforts are combined with UX (user experience). Other relevant web disciplines can be content strategy, accessibility and information architecture.

\n

Web Governance Roles

\n

Especially in terms of SEO, Web Governance roles can help strengthen the position of the discipline in the daily management of the website. Because SEO is a long term discipline where results are not immediately visible, there will often be a tendency to side track SEO in stressful situations, particularly when roles and responsibilities are not clearly defined. If everyone in the team is aware of their own and colleagues' roles and responsibilities, they feel greater commitment to the task and towards colleagues, and therefore more likely to priorities the task.

\n

Web Standards

\n

As Bo Vejgaard has described in a previous blog post about Web Governance, web standards have a number of rules designed to ensure the quality of the organization's web presence.
From an SEO point of view, it means that the optimization work will be easier if SEO is included in the organization's web standards, so that employees no longer need to spend time discussing what you can and cannot do and what they should spend their time working on. An organization's SEO standards could include:

\n
    \n
  • All pages on the organization's website should include a meta description that complies with best practice as described in the procedures.
    • \n
  • All pages on the organization's website should have a unique page title (title tag) to describe the content, contain one or more relevant keywords and end with dash and organization name.
    • \n
  • All images on the organization's website must have image alt texts that describe what the image is about and should contain relevant keywords.
    • \n
  • H-tags (headers) should only be used for the actual content and not for menu items, fixed elements, etc..
    • \n
  • Each page on the organization's website may contain only one H1 tag to be used as the main headline.
    • \n
\n


If standards like these have been firmly rooted in the organization, it is also easier to avoid the SEO campaign being weakened by individual web editors' anarchy - like for instance when an editor fails to write a meta description for a page, because the meta description is not visible in the published website (the meta description is only visible in the page's source code and is used as the description under the page title in search engines' search results), and therefore does not seem important.

\n

Procedures

\n

With feet heavily planted in web standards, then employees can find additional guidance in the procedures that have been implemented for SEO. These could include instructions on how to write search engine friendly text, or how to create a focus keyword.
Besides functioning as a guide for web editors, these procedures also ensure that knowledge is not lost when employees leave the job.

\n

Evaluation

\n

Last but not least, there must be continuous evaluation on the compliance of standards and procedures;

\n
    \n
  • Whether they are up-to-date
    • \n
  • Whether the goals set for SEO have been obtained, and are on the right track,
    • \n
  • If the SEO strategy should be revised
    • \n
\n

These are some of the ways Web Governance can help you make sure that your SEO efforts are successful.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\nWeb Developers: Create an Accessible Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n\n
\n

This week's blog post is the second in a three-part series covering websites and accessibility with a role-based approach for Web designers, web developers and web editors. This contribution is meant for web developers. The previous was intended for web designers and the final is meant for web editors. In each post, I give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n

Include the remaining 20% of users

\n

Surveys show that up to 20% of web users are affected by accessibility issues when surfing the web. By following the principles of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines you ensure that as many people as possible can use a website. In the following paragraphs I will give tips on which criteria are relevant for you as a web designer.

\n

Page titles

\n

Make sure that all web pages have a descriptive title reflecting the page content. Also make sure that web editors can enter page titles via the authoring tool (for example CMS).

\n

Keyboard navigation

\n

All content on a web page should be navigable both with a computer mouse and from the keyboard alone. This applies to forms, buttons and links for instance.

\n

Some users are not able to use a computer mouse. They can use the keyboard only to navigate by tabbing through content on a web page. These users need to be able to see where they are located on the page. For this reason it should always be visually evident where on the web page the tab indicator is located. Most browsers automatically show this with a dotted line around the content. You can also implement your own way of showing this.

\n

Content sequence

\n

When content for web pages is coded make sure that the content, not only visually but also in the coding sequence, has a meaningful order. Some users navigate pages by this order. Ensure that the order of content is sensible when styles are disabled and when tabbing through content.

\n

Enlarging

\n

Make sure web page text can be resized up to 200% as a minimum, and still be usable and look sensible (newer browsers can zoom content and this is usually the way that assistive technologies do it as well).

\n

Language

\n

In order for user agents to be able to render content in the correct language, it is important that the pages have a correct language definition in the HTML tag for a web page. The language tag should be 'en' for English pages for instance and 'da' for Danish pages and so on.

\n

Also the CMS should give web editors the ability to highlight text that is in a different language than the rest of the page. The highlighting should add the lang="" attribute into the code.

\n

Coding

\n

In order to make sure that the website is shown consistently across different platforms (such as operating systems and browsers) and ensure technologies can render content in a meaningful way, the standard for the format one publishes in should be complied with. If, for instance, you are publishing in XHTML 1.0 or HTML 5.0 the syntax rules for this format should be followed. You can check your web pages for syntax errors at: http://validator.w3.org/.

\n

Also make sure that elements are marked up with the correct tags. For example, HTML headings should be tagged as <h1></h1> (h1…h6).

\n

Data tables should be tagged as <table> and web editors should be able to add descriptions to data tables via <caption>. Headings for columns and rows should be defined by the use of <th> and perhaps 'header id' and 'scope'. If a complex data table needs explaining for screen reader users, then this should be done via 'summary'.

\n

When writing text, web editors should be able to emphasize with <strong> and <em>.

\n

When form elements are used, a label should be explicitly connected to each control and form elements that belong to the same group should be assembled. For instance a group of radio buttons should be grouped with<fieldset> and <legend>. There are a number of techniques to ensure this: Techniques for 1.3.1 and Techniques for 4.1.2.

\n

User input

\n

If the user is to enter information in a text field, make sure that where the user does not enter text in the right format the user is notified with text, and if possible help the user correct the mistake. When filling out a form that is part of a financial transaction or a legal commitment where data is changed, the input must be checked by the system to avoid errors or the user should have the option of reading through the input before sending it. A third option is that the user can always reverse the submission.

\n

Graphics

\n

When web pages contain elements that are non-textual it is important to give a textual alternative describing the purpose of the non-text element. This for instance can be an image. For images the HTML attribute for alt text is used (alt=""). It is important to note that the alternative text reflects the purpose of the image and not necessarily what the image is of. The authoring tool (such as a CMS) should allow for entering alternative texts on images that are displayed on web pages. The alt attribute should always be tagged on all images, and should allow the web editor either to leave the field empty or give a description for an image. An alternative text is context specific, so it can be poor accessibility practice to enter a single alternative text for every instance of a specific image when uploading to the media library. Your authoring tool should allow you to enter a new alternative text every time an image is used on a web page.

\n

If a web page contains a media file, it should also be given a descriptive text either as an alt attribute or in the object tag on inline elements and the like.

\n

Audio and video

\n

When you publish audio and video on a web page, give an alternative format and add captions and audio description.

\n

Make sure that all buttons and navigation in the video player can be used both with a computer mouse and with the keyboard alone. Give all the buttons and navigation text descriptions to help screen readers.

\n

For a video you should be able to enter a dedicated track for audio description and also the option to add captions.  If a passage of audio starts automatically, the user should be able to pause, stop, or control the sound volume.

\n

User control

\n

Some users need a long time to read and navigate web pages. Therefore, if some sort of time limit is present on pages, such as a time out, the user must be able to change the limit either by adjusting it, extending, or disabling it.

\n

If content for moving, blinking or scrolling is added, it is also important that the user can pause, stop or hide this content.

\n

In order for screen reader users to avoid having to listen to the same content every time they load a new page, provide the option of skipping blocks of repeated content. Repeated content can be a global menu (and local menu) and help functions. There are several techniques for ensuring this. The easiest way is to provide a link at the top of all pages that takes the user to the main content of the page (for instance the heading 1 on the page in the content section). There are other options as well: Techniques for 2.4.1.

\n

When an element is to be altered by the user, such as a drop down menu, a radio button or the like, it is important that it acts as the user expects. Elements should not react solely from receiving focus or when the user lands on it from the keyboard. It should react when the user has had the time to choose and confirm.

\n

Blinking content

\n

In terms of the above, specifically for blinking content, this should not happen with a frequency of more than three times a second, otherwise it may cause an epileptic episode for some users.

\n

If you would like to know what web designers and web editors should focus on, you can read my whitepaper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792134861:\n\n\n\n\n\nTop 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nTop 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n\n
\n

Accessibility aims at making web content accessible for as many users as possible, including those who are limited by a handicap. Search engines have a lot in common with the visually impaired; for instance they cannot 'see' images, video content and JavaScript. The ability to have web page content interpreted and rendered mechanically is therefore of great importance to both search engines and users of assistive technologies.

\n

Here are the top 5 most important overlaps:

\n

1)   Page titles

\n

The page title is the most important on-page SEO element. Therefore the page title should describe the page content accurately, include important keywords, and be unique for every page. If you insist on including your company name, it should be placed after the keywords. At the same time the page title is the first thing a screen reader renders to the user. For this reason it is important that the page title provides a good description of what is expected from the page content.

\n

2)   Headings

\n

Headings must be 'real' headings (<H>) and not just styled to look like one, in order for search engines to recognize them as headings. Every page must have one H1 heading (the most important heading) where important keywords should be included. To make the page more readable, you can divide it into sub sections with H2 sub headings - ideally also including important keywords. For instance, if you have a visual impairment and are unable to get an overview of a web page visually, you need to have an overview in another way. This can be done by pulling out a list of headings on a page, which is why it is important that headings on the page are also headings in the code and that they are used to divide content into logical sections.

\n

3)   Alt texts

\n

Alternative texts were originally created to provide a text alternative to users that are unable to see an image. Search engines likewise cannot 'see' an image. Instead they use the alternative text to understand what the image is showing and what its function is. Therefore, an alt text must describe the contents of an image. Make sure to include important keywords - but only if it makes sense in the context of the image. If a visually impaired user is not able to see an image it is often of vital importance that an image be supplied with an alt text that reflects the purpose of the image.

\n

4)   Link texts (anchor texts)

\n

A link text should describe the page that it's linking to. Generic texts such as 'click here' and 'read more' do not provide any information to the search engine about the destination page. The same applies to users of screen readers when they try to get an overview of a web page. Often they may pull out a list of links on a page or tab between links, so it's important that the link text makes sense also when read out of its context.

\n

5)   Sensory Instructions

\n

If you are referring the user to a certain area/element on the web page make sure that you do it in a way that enables all users to find it. A screen reader renders content to the user in one long sequence. For this reason there is no design or any columns when a user of screen reader receives content. Avoid for example saying: "You can find more information in the box to your right". Instead combine it with some text saying: "You can find more information in the box to your right with the heading 'Information about…' Search engines also do not understand sensory characteristics, so you aren't gaining anything by saying "in the box to your right." Instead use sensible (search) terms explaining what you are referring to.

\n

Also consider:

\n

a.    Transcription of video content    

\n

Search engines and visually impaired users are unable to 'see' video. Therefore, it is a good idea to make a transcript of the content so that screen readers and search engines can read the text and thereby make it available for search engines.

\n

b.      Text in images

\n

Text in an image is still just an image. To make search engines and read-aloud tools capable of reading the text it must be real text and not an image of text. Also, text in images cannot be adapted to fit users needs such as changing text size, font or colors.

\n

c.       JavaScript in menus

\n

Search engines are not always able to understand JavaScript which makes it a bad idea to use JavaScript in menus. Worst case scenario is that the search engines are only accessing the front page while all other pages are not found in search results. Always use ordinary text links in menus. Another issue is that menus and other content made with JavaScript sometimes can only be activated by mouseOver and not via keyboard focus. This is often an issue and makes the web page work poorly or not at all if you are navigating by keyboard alone (and cannot use a computer mouse).

\n

d.      Content Sequence

\n

Search engines and some users read a page from top to bottom (sequentially). Make sure that important content is given initially.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792137291:\n\n\n\n\n\nWinter Analytics Checklist for Your Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n

\n

\nWinter Analytics Checklist for Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\n

Busy as a bee during the Holidays?

\n
\n
\n

If your organization picks up during the holidays try focusing on simple and attainable objectives you/the team can implement. Some examples may include:

\n

Create a report to identify the most popular “entry pages” into your website.  Understanding the origin of your visitor, creating content to match their interests, and easy navigation are critical to ensure a low bounce rate.  By improving the top entry pages to match the intended visitor’s interest, the organization fosters a stronger engagement with the user.  If you are running a holiday-specific campaign, you could consider optimizing your landing pages to ensure your visitors find what they want.

\n

\n

Evaluate your website by grouping similar pages to each other and review each group’s objective.  Are your visitors’ actions matching up with what the web team wanted or hoped for? Analyze the top pages of each group and identify if the visitor journey correlates to your organization’s objectives.  Creating a clear route within each group towards the objective ensures visitors are finding what they seek.

\n

\n

Segment your analytics data by external referrals and compare the traffic each source generates to your website. By monitoring your multi-channel marketing efforts, you’ll see exactly what advertisements your visitors click and also deliver your organization the greatest gross profit. You’ll also better understand the channels that your visitors prefer.  Be sure your organization’s website analytics tool tracks all clicks related to your marketing and website objectives, if not, what’s the point?!

\n

\n

Slower like a Sloth?  

\n

If your company slows down during the holidays envision your next year’s web analytics goals. By developing these analytics aspirations to actionable and quantifiable goals before the upcoming year, you will be able to start the year on the right foot. Now who doesn’t like that? 

\n

Track down broken links on your website and fix them.  Especially links clicked most often.  By fixing these errors, you will help visitors find the information they are looking for, without abandoning your site. This will also improve the websites bounce rate and visitor frustration, but most importantly eliminating the user from heading to your competitor’s.

\n

\n

Create a campaign tracking program to identify how users navigate to the website.  By tracking the sources of advertising that the Marketing Department use, you’ll have a more thorough overview on what types of marketing efforts work to drive the most interest to the organization’s website.  A great starting place for this project would be to track campaigns for email blasts, Pay–Per-Click (PPC), and blogs posts.

\n

\n

Is your website a driver for ROI or is it predominately informational?  Go through your website and track the pages which highlight your organization’s actionable goals. By tracking the pages where the most desired conversions occur, you will be able to easily scrutinize why certain pages do not produce the desired outcome.  In addition, you will also be able to see whether your visitor’s objectives match your organization’s website layout.

\n

For example, we can see that a majority of people who entered through our company’s homepage filled out our company’s demo request form and arrived at the Siteimprove “thank you” page. By tracking pages with our company’s demo request form, we can compare and analyze why our homepage draws more desired conversions and also find other ways to encourage visitors to sign up on pages other than the home page to increase overall ROI.

\n

\n

These suggestions are not exclusive and each organization will have different focuses, goals and internal programs implemented throughout the year.  This is a starting point to understanding your web analytics data and provides answers and suggestions to your department’s website objectives.

\n

Coauthored by Steve Hennigs and Kitty Ng.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n\n
\n

While all three stages of the content strategy lifecycle are intended to be ongoing, it is the governance stage that often requires the most dedication due to its never ending need for attention. Once content is created and published then it will forever need governing, which leads to the age old question of where to begin.

During this stage it’s easy to get overwhelmed which is why at Siteimprove we always find it helpful to follow the four D’s:

\n

Define, Develop, Determine and Do. 

\n

1. Define the roles of authority 

\n

Successful content governance requires a concrete understanding of who is in charge of making decisions about your website. While it may seem easier said than done, one way to help enforce roles of authority is via the use of an easy task and responsibility management tool. For example, all of the intuitive web management tools available in Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite allow for role assignment, and therefore make it easier to see whether people are governing the content they are responsible for.

\n

Easy task and responsibility assignment

\n

This is especially useful for those organizations that may have 100,000’s of pages on their site, with just as many different areas of focus. Instead of people trying to haphazardly govern content, they will instead be able to have a clear oversight of what areas of the website they are responsible for.  

\n

2. Develop a plan with tools

\n

A clear content strategy plan should hopefully help you from launch to ongoing maintenance, and with the use of tools it’ll be even easier to systematically govern, maintain, and market all of your online content using one platform. Our fully integrated five-in-one suite contains quality assurance, accessibility, analytics, SEO and Response tools, and is a practical solution for adhering to a plan. 

\n

Devolve content into bite size chunks

\n

Tackling website governance can be difficult even with a plan which is why focusing on content in smaller more specific sections can be a great idea. Instead of webmasters or the web-team trying to quickly get an overview of all content, the use of the Siteimprove Web Governance Suite ‘Groups’ feature allows users to structure sections of their website’s content, which can then be used as easy building blocks for effective governance.

\n

Improve the consistency of your voice and tone

\n

An integral part of planning for content governance is consistency. It is essential to adhere to the same tone of voice for all content, otherwise quality-effecting errors can occur. A clear language policy can be extremely helpful in this regard. Searching for misspellings, branding mishaps, and jargon that you may wish to exclude from all pages, are unique features of the Siteimprove Quality Assurance tool. With the use of our ‘Word List’ feature it’ll be easy to locate those words that no longer suit your company ethos, all of which will help in enhancing your users’ experience and strengthening your brand image.

\n

 

\n

3. Determine if it’s working

\n

Once you start governing your content then it also becomes necessary to determine the effectiveness of your content, is it working in the way you had envisaged, and if not then how can you set about fixing it. Once content is created and published then it is necessary to analyze whether it has effectively met your content strategy goals. In our first blog, The three components of Content Strategy success, we introduced industry expert Kristina Halvorson’s argument that high quality web content must be useful, usable, and enjoyable in order for it to give you the greatest online competitive advantage.

\n

 

\n

Analyze the stats

\n

Answering the question of how to tell whether your content is doing everything it should, is easy with an analytics tool such as Siteimprove’s. With an easy interface that takes only 20 minutes to learn it’s never been easier to have the must-know stats right at your fingertips. With Siteimprove Analytics ‘Summary’ feature it’s simple to see the most, and least, popular pages, entry and exit pages, as well as a wealth of other data. 

\n

Ensure your content is wrapped in accurate metadata

\n

If you find that your content isn’t working as hoped then perhaps the problem could lie with your search engine optimization efforts. In that case it is usually a good idea to invest in an advanced SEO tool rather than try manually to identify problems. A feature such as Siteimprove’s SEO ‘Page Header’ can be an ideal way to detect and fix duplicate or missing meta descriptions, all of which will help you to achieve greater visibility in search results and a richer user experience when browsing.

\n

 

\n

4. Do it everyday

\n

The last content governance step may seem so simple it’s stupid but it’s actually the hardest. While anyone can define the roles and responsibilities of people, plan like there’s no tomorrow, and analyze the stats, it takes a true Master Content Enforcer to ensure that it’s all being done everyday, which is why good tools are a must.

\n

Be certain your content responds and remains intact

\n

The best way to ensure that you’ll be able to govern your sites content effectively is to ensure that your site is working as intended. Siteimprove Response is a stress-free option for monitoring your key pages response times, as well as uptime and downtime. This is done 24/7 from a global servers which means being kept informed about the integrity of your website’s content is ensured. Plus because our servers never sleep it means you’ll be able to with a good conscious, knowing that if things go wrong you’ll be instantly alerted by email and SMS.  

\n

 

\n

Strategizing towards the future

\n

Throughout our content strategy blog series we have looked at what constitutes a successful content strategy, as well as at the different natural life cycles that it goes through. From creation, to publication, and finally ongoing governance, we hope that our series has helped to shed light on one of the industries newest emerging practices.

\n

As always we welcome comments and would love to hear your thoughts on what it takes to successfully implement a content strategy.  

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792144991:\n\n\n\n\n\nContent Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nContent Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n\n

Managing your online content marketing efforts requires a dedicated team, relevant strategies, and an understanding of your website’s needs. That’s where Web Governance comes in. A web governance tool will help you to quickly identify the most pressing needs for your website and allow you to build the right team, create the right strategy, and develop a proactive approach to website management. 

\n

What is Content Marketing?

\n

Content marketing is the byproduct of a society that has been saturated with traditional marketing. Where technology once enabled businesses to reach consumers anywhere at any time, it has now allowed those same consumers to skip, block, and altogether ignore your unsolicited marketing advances.

\n

Content marketing is the practice of creating and distributing valuable, relevant, and consistent content in order to attract your target audience. Consumers are more educated and more savvy than ever, so simply telling them what to do or what to buy just won’t fly anymore. Content marketing aims to show them how your organization can provide the product or service that they’re looking for.

\n

What is Web Governance?

\n

Web governance is the byproduct of our Internet dominated world.  Just look at that last sentence, Internet is capitalized because it’s a proper noun now. That’s a reflection of just how important it is to our society, and how much we depend on it as an information sharing and communication platform.

\n

Web governance refers to the systems and practices used to manage your Internet presence. As your presence grows, web governance enables your organization to maintain stability and focus on its online goals.

\n

How They Work Together

\n

Content Consistency

\n

You’ve spent a lot of time and energy (and probably money) creating content that is relevant, useful, and targeted to your audience. If you haven’t done so, just keep reading and pretend that you have, we won’t tell. Over time, new content will be added, old content will need to be updated or removed, and brand standards will evolve. But as your site grows, managing that content becomes more difficult and manually checking every single page becomes physically impossible.

\n

Moving or updating content can lead to broken links, misspellings can slip through the cracks as content is handed off from writers to developers, and legal/regulatory disclaimers will need to be monitored for accuracy. Web governance tools and strategies will help you monitor page content as it changes to ensure quality and consistency on a large scale.

\n

Team Roles & Responsibilities

\n

As your website grows, so too (hopefully) will the team who manages it. This opens the door for two potential and equally frustrating issues- overlapping responsibilities and responsibility gaps. The obvious problems caused by both are bad enough, but the worst part is that they often aren’t noticed until it’s too late.

\n

Having a website governance strategy in place will allow you to identify key tasks and areas of responsibility for the members of your team. This will allow you to minimize errors, improve communication, and maximize your team’s efficiency. Check out Shane Diffily's recent blog to learn more.

\n

Project Prioritization

\n

Managing a huge website with a small team and a smaller budget means adopting a reactive strategy, one where you’re constantly putting out fires and working on whichever project you’re getting harassed about the most. This can lead to a stressful work environment and prevent you from completing the most important projects.

\n

Employing a website governance tool means being able to monitor your website content’s effectiveness, which allows your team to prioritize the projects and areas that need to be addressed, and when. This helps you effectively manage your team, keep key stakeholders updated on the progress you’re making, and defend the decisions you’re making based on factual data.

\n

Employing the proper website governance tools and strategies will help you manage your content, maintain a positive work environment for your team, and ultimately achieve your online goals.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792147301:\n\n\n\n\n\nFive Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nFive Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/30/13 2:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n\n
\n

1. Not asking yourself why

\n

Having a website is a must-have for most professional companies, yet the guiding rationale for most new web projects is “we need to have one,” rather than defining what the site should actually achieve.

Creating a website merely to be a glorified company business card is common, but not a particularly effective method of utilizing the web.  Your resources might be put to better use by flinging money out of the office windows - at least that way you’d attract crowds of people and maybe a news crew.

\n

The best way to begin a web project is to brainstorm specific ways the site will provide visitors with true value. That should be the basis on which you start your design process.

Websites with value = more time spent on your site = higher chance of them doing business with you = $

\n

2. Building a website that pleases management

\n

Of course it’s important that management likes the new website, but it’s even more important that it pleases your visitors. Company pages, about us sections, mission statements, and corporate history all have their place on a website - but shouldn’t be the majority of content. Instead, focus on building a site that your target audience will love.   Management is not your target audience.

\n

3. Contracting work out to numerous agencies 

\n

A company may choose to outsource various tasks to agencies, and while this can ensure work is completed quickly and professionally it can also have negative design consequences if handled incorrectly. When deciding to outsource tasks, limit the number of agencies you will work with. If you’re not careful, your site could easily end up looking like a patchwork quilt. 

\n

Design inconsistencies are irritating to users and can make navigating a site a logistical nightmare. On the other hand, consistency will improve usability giving users increased confidence, which may result in a higher likelihood of them perusing your site in detail.   

The solution to inconsistent design is to ensure that one overarching body is responsible for designing the entire site. In some cases this won’t be possible, however it is still advisable to have one group whose job it is to oversee design and ensure guidelines are being followed. 

\n

4. Underestimating the role of content

\n

Whether you are designing your website for the first time or undertaking a redesign, understand the role content will play before you get started. Often websites are designed first and then content is made to fit, rather than the other way around. Interestingly, content (not design) is the reason people visit your site.

When building a brand new website it is essential to understand that the web is a unique medium and will require unique content. Whilst it may be easier to recycle content from other mediums such as brochures and booklets the result will often be a content heavy site that doesn’t meet the users’ expectations.

Similarly, content should play a major role when undertaking a redesign. Unfortunately this is rarely the case and when a newly designed site has the same old content it will usually fail to meet the needs and expectations of users, which can prove costly.

To overcome these issues, consider investing in a content team or individual whose only job is to design new or refreshed web content. Ideally this person or people should have experience creating content specifically for web, as opposed to other mediums. The implementation of editorial guidelines can also prove helpful in ensuring that content created by a team for large websites is consistent across the board.

\n

5. Impractical market research  

\n

The use of market research is not new, yet many companies are still failing to go the extra mile to understand how users will operate within the design. All too often companies spend time and money on focus groups where they talk about the site’s design, instead of employing usability engineering methods to actually see what happens when people interact with a site. While focus groups can be useful for gathering information about users’ concerns and needs, users should be given the chance to test a prototype design and see whether it works for them.

\n

A good method involves combining market research with usability engineering so that you can see which elements of your design may confuse users, slow them down, or simply don’t work as intended.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n

\nUser Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n\n
\n

Make your users web ambassadors and build a close relationship

\n

By creating an opportunity for user feedback on the website you have the possibility to create a closer relationship with your users and thereby minimize the risk of a bad user experience and the prospect of users swopping to other more costly channels of communication.

\n

User feedback is extremely valuable as it makes it easy for you to convert actual user experience into online improvements; here are a few examples of real user feedback:

\n

Feedback relating to web content and usability:

\n

"I'm looking for a phone number I can call for questions relating to issuing a new passport, but I can't find it on the page!"

\n

Feedback relating to self-service solutions and web forms

\n

"I'm experiencing problems downloading the forms on this site on a Mac?"

\n

Feedback relating to seasonal changes

\n

"I've spent a lot of time looking for opening hours during Easter, but couldn't find them."

\n

If your users feel you listen there's a great chance that they will change their role from simple users to web ambassadors telling others about their successful experience and maybe even give feedback on other issues on you website.

\n

Cure your blindness

\n

You can probably find your way around your website in your sleep, but this often makes you blind to navigating your website from an outside perspective. So why not ask your users if they find what they are looking for on the website? This way you get an extra set of eyes and thereby cure your blindness.

\n

User feedback - the cherry on top of your web analysis

\n

When implementing a user feedback tool on your website I would recommend you look for a tool that integrates with your web analysis service. Think of the extra dimension you could add to your web analysis data by being able to filter user ratings and comments on your most visited and/or important pages!     

\n

"We spend a lot of resources analyzing the overall visits and user behavior on our website but at the end of the day the figures do not give us a clear understanding as to whether or not the users actually find what they are looking for online. Therefore we are very happy with our new feedback module. The feedback helps us continuously improve the website, get rid of any errors and get an overview of "what works and what does not." All with the objective of making the website as user friendly as possible,"

\n

-Anja Flebbe, Web and multimedia staff, The Municipality of Horsens.

\n

Allocate resources and prepare yourself for straightforward feedback

\n

Before you open up for user feedback on your website, there are two things you may consider.

\n
    \n
  1. Allocate the necessary resources so that users find that their feedback is taken seriously.
     When opening up a new channel you must be prepared to take action and implement the constructive criticism and new ideas on your website. Depending on the size of your website, the amount of feedback may vary. During February to March 2012, the Danish Municipality of Horsens, got 700 ratings and comments on the website.
    2. \n
    \n
  1. Feedback with no filter. 
     Users tend to take their time to give feedback when they are either very happy or dissatisfied with your website. When giving feedback users are normally anonymous which means that comments are unfiltered. Therefore I would recommend identifying a group of web administrators who act as a filter and only pass on the constructive comments to the rest of the web team and editors. 
    2. \n
\n

About user feedback

\n

There are many different user feedback services. Siteimprove's new User Feedback module is an add on service to Siteimprove Analytics.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nThe 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\n
\n

Research

\n

Usually the first thing people focus on when creating content is research. It’s what helps formulate your ideas, as well assists you in planning how to take those thoughts and turn them into useful, usable and enjoyable content that help meet your business objectives. One great way to research is to look at how your developing site or existing site’s content is meeting and engaging people’s expectations and needs.

\n

Map your users

\n

The Siteimprove analytics tool is ideal for this, as its ‘User Journey’ feature is able to assist you with mapping user journeys and understanding where users come from, all of which helps in deciding on what content to create or use. 

\n

Analytics information can also be used to help with everything from documenting your results, to making your case for management to allocate the resources needed, to analysis that supports the graphical design.

\n

Knowing the geographic location of your users, their technical specifications, and whether or not they use computers or mobile devices when visiting your website will also give you a clearer picture of your users.

\n

\n

Know your users

\n

Analytics data can provide specific and accurate answers to essential questions that anyone who has a website should know, such as:

\n
    \n
  • Who are our users?
    • \n
  • What content on our current website do they look at?
    • \n
  • How do they end up on our current website?
    • \n
  • What do they do/where do they go when they visit the website?
    • \n
  • What feedback have we received from our users?
    • \n
\n

Data found using the Siteimprove Analytics ‘Content’ feature can also assist you in learning how user needs drive the statistics and metrics, which can in turn help you make decisions about what content goes on the site, and what doesn’t.

\n

\n

Optimize your content

\n

Search engine optimization is also an extremely helpful aspect to consider during the creation stage. Tools, such as Siteimprove SEO are ideal for shedding some much-needed light on whether or not your content is going to be discoverable by potential users.

\n

Using Siteimprove’s newest intuitive SEO feature, ‘Keywords’ for example, allows you to monitor important keywords by analyzing search results so that you can effectively optimize your pages and get better search engine rankings. Therefore, this enables you to strategically plan and create content that builds your brand and optimizes your site.

\n

\n

While content strategy creation may be an ongoing process, it is one that can be made easier with the use of quality website management and diagnostic tools - such as those from Siteimprove.   

\n

For more tips and tricks on reducing the anxiety of implementing a content strategy throughout the publishing stage stay tuned for the next installment. As always, feel free to comment, and if you enjoyed this post, please share it.

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\n6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\n
\n

1. Define roles and responsibilities among your team.

\n

One of the best ways to catch website issues is to ensure that they never occur in the first place. Having clearly set roles and responsibilities throughout your development team is the perfect way to ensure that everything is taken care of from start to finish. This removes any ambiguity regarding who is responsible for the finished project at the end, and ensures that no one makes changes to certain parts of the project after it has been completed.

\n

Good communication is essential for a solid development team, but good software is also important. Project management software will be the foundation upon which your development team builds. You need not only a capable software suite but also well-defined protocols regarding communication, when it should be done and where it should be done. As an example, consistent note-taking within the project management software itself can greatly sidestep any issues and stopping points.

\n

2. Perform regular inventories of web content.

\n

Many people don't consider "outdated content" to be a website issue, but today, it's a serious one. Outdated content or content that is flawed can quickly plummet your website ranking, leading to as many problems overall as you would have had if your website didn't work at all. You should regularly inventory your web content to ensure that it is all current and that it is all working.

\n

Links, in particular, may degrade over time. Sending people to an incorrect web address is terrible, and loading an image that no longer exists is even worse; it looks unprofessional, distracts them and again, sends your web ranking tumbling downwards. An automated system is the best solution for those that want to regularly inventory their web content: it can complete the inventory behind the scenes on a regular basis.

\n

3. Use automation to your benefit.

\n

No one is perfect. Even your developers and your website testers may miss something from time to time, and that is why automated error discovery is so incredibly important. Automated website checking can comb every corner of your website thoroughly and can discover things that others might miss, such as pages that are no longer in compliance with current web standards. These are things that aren't necessarily visible to the human eye, but will be visible to search engines.

\n

4. Conduct speed and stress tests.

\n

Many of the issues that occur with a website won't occur until it is actually pushed to the limit. You may not realize that your server will break under the strain of high traffic, or that your current website is utilizing more memory and processing time than is really viable. Conducting speed and stress tests are the only way to replicate an actual operating environment and ensure that things don't go wrong when you least expect it.

\n

5. Anticipate the things that can go wrong.

\n

Regardless of how much error checking you do, there are things that might go wrong. Anticipating these problems and reacting to them in advance is how you can minimize the damage. Having custom error pages to ensure that clients don't get lost on your site is a fantastic way to make sure that they'll stay on the site should the worst happen.

\n

You should also have contingency plans in place for if the website does go down, and a clear system of responsibilities that tells your team who is responsible for acting if an emergency does occur.

\n

6. Pay attention to your analytics.

\n

Occasionally, something could go wrong and you might have no idea. There are things that could go wrong on your website that might not be noticeable, and paying attention to your analytic data is a fantastic way to ensure that you catch these issues before they get any worse. Your statistics can show you tremendous volumes of information if you let it.

\n

Your bounce rate, as well as the average time your visitors spend on your website, will be able to tell you quite a lot. If these indicators suddenly change, there could be a problem that you don't know about, such as a server load increase that's causing pages to lag.

\n

Maintaining a website can seem like a tremendous chore, but there are many ways that you can make it easier on both yourself and your team. An all-in-one solution like Siteimprove can be used to catch issues before they become a problem. Siteimprove can crawl your website on a regular basis to ensure the fidelity of links, the accessibility of the site and the site's overall quality. It can even provide valuable analytics and alert your entire team should something go wrong.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Raising Digital Discrimination Awareness

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/21/13 3:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Imagine that you’re suddenly blind, maybe unable to make your body function as it did before, perhaps you can no longer read without difficulty or distinguish between colors, conceivably you may just be getting older… Now try accessing the web.

\n
\n
\n

Many people find it difficult to imagine what accessing the web may be like without the basic physical and cognitive traits we often take for granted. Aimed to get people talking, thinking and learning about the estimated 20% of the population with some kind of a disability, Global Accessibility Awareness Day has again concluded for another year - but not without some important lessons being learned the hard way.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get a head start by quality assuring your development site

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n12/19/12 2:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many of our customers launched new websites in 2012, and took advantage of running our Quality Assurance and Accessibility checks on the development website. Finding and fixing errors on their website prior to launching is helpful in it's own right, but allowing the web developers early access to the tools has proven to be invaluable.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n

  • \n\n

    • \n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n

    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.
